did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia Annual Reports, Bulletins, and Occasional Miscellanies

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art. The Library Company's Annual Report includes president's, director's, and treasurer's reports, and descriptions of notable acquisitions, gifts, and donations. The Bulletin consists of a list of books recently acquired by the Library Company, arranged by topic. The Bulletin also contains the rules of the Library Company. The Occasional Miscellany is a newsletter that provides information about endowments and funding, acquisition highlights, work being done in conservation lab, and other topics. Librarian's Reports are typed reports of library usage and acquisitions.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the Library Company's Annual Reports, Bulletins and Occasional Miscellanies. The Annual Reports date from 1879, 1903-1934 (some years missing), 1935-1942, 1947-1949, and 1951-2005. Additionally there are two reels of microfilm of annual reports from 1874 to 1987 (some issues missing). Bulletins date from 1841-1938, 1940-1841, 1945, 1958, 1966-1968. There are copies of the Occasional Miscellany from 1977-2005. The collection also includes Librarian's reports, 1953-1983.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
